answer_html: But for the real solution, it is enough to only consider \(\displaystyle v_a e^{\lambda_at}\).”
answer_latex:
But for the real solution, it is
enough to only consider $\displaystyle v_a e^{\lambda_at}$.''
hints_html:
The general real solution of a linear ordinary differential equation \(\displaystyle y'(t) = My\) is given by

\(\displaystyle y(t) = C_1\mathrm{Re}\left( v_ae^{\lambda_a t}\right) + C_2\mathrm{Im}\left( v_ae^{\lambda_at}\right)\)

where \(\displaystyle \lambda_a\) is one of the eigenvalues of the matrix \(\displaystyle M\) with appropriate eigenvector \(\displaystyle v_a\).

For our ODE \(\displaystyle y' = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & -2\\ 4 & -1\end{bmatrix}y\) do the following:

  • Calculate the eigenvalues \(\displaystyle \lambda_{a,b}\) of the matrix \(\displaystyle M=\begin{bmatrix} 3 & -2\\4 & -1\end{bmatrix}\).

  • Determine one of the eigenvectors \(\displaystyle v_a\).

  • Separate the expression \(\displaystyle v_a e^{\lambda_at}\) in real and imaginary part.

  • Write general constans \(\displaystyle C_1, C_2\) as factors to real and imaginary part and remove the \(\displaystyle i\).
hints_latex:
The general real solution of a linear ordinary differential equation
$\displaystyle y'(t) = My$ is given by

$\displaystyle y(t) = C_1\mathrm{Re}\left( v_ae^{\lambda_a t}\right) + C_2\mathrm{Im}\left( v_ae^{\lambda_at}\right)$

where $\displaystyle \lambda_a$ is one of the eigenvalues of the matrix
$\displaystyle M$ with appropriate eigenvector $\displaystyle v_a$.

For our ODE
$\displaystyle y' = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & -2\\ 4 & -1\end{bmatrix}y$ do
the following:

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  Calculate the eigenvalues $\displaystyle \lambda_{a,b}$ of the matrix
  $\displaystyle M=\begin{bmatrix} 3 &  -2\\4 & -1\end{bmatrix}$.
\item
  Determine one of the eigenvectors $\displaystyle v_a$.
\item
  Separate the expression $\displaystyle v_a e^{\lambda_at}$ in real and
  imaginary part.
\item
  Write general constans $\displaystyle C_1, C_2$ as factors to real and
  imaginary part and remove the $\displaystyle i$.
\end{itemize}
hints_raw:
The general real solution of a linear ordinary differential equation <math> \displaystyle y'(t) = My</math> is given by

<math>\displaystyle 
y(t) = C_1\mathrm{Re}\left( v_ae^{\lambda_a t}\right) + C_2\mathrm{Im}\left( v_ae^{\lambda_at}\right)
</math>

where <math> \displaystyle \lambda_a </math> is one of the eigenvalues of the matrix <math> \displaystyle M</math> with appropriate eigenvector <math> \displaystyle v_a</math>.
For our ODE <math> \displaystyle y' = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & -2\\ 4 & -1\end{bmatrix}y</math> do the following:

* Calculate the eigenvalues <math> \displaystyle\lambda_{a,b}</math> of the matrix <math> \displaystyle M=\begin{bmatrix} 3 &  -2\\4 & -1\end{bmatrix}</math>.
* Determine one of the eigenvectors <math>\displaystyle v_a</math>.
* Separate the expression <math> \displaystyle v_a e^{\lambda_at}</math> in real and imaginary part.
* Write general constans <math> \displaystyle C_1, C_2 </math> as factors to real and imaginary part and remove the <math> \displaystyle i </math>.
question: B 06 (b)
sols_html:
To begin, we compute the eigenvalues of the matrix from part (a) (call this matrix M). To start, compute the characteristic polynomial.

\[\begin{aligned} \det(M-\lambda I) &= \det\left( \begin{bmatrix} 3 & -2 \\ 4 & -1 \end{bmatrix} - \lambda \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\right) \\ &= \det\left( \begin{bmatrix} 3-\lambda & -2 \\ 4 & -1-\lambda \end{bmatrix}\right) \\ &= (3-\lambda)(-1-\lambda)-(-2)(4) \\ &= -3 -2\lambda +\lambda^{2} + 8\\ &= \lambda^{2} -2\lambda + 5 \end{aligned}\]

This polynomial has two complex roots given by

\[\begin{aligned} \lambda &= \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^{2}-4ac}}{2a}\\ &= \frac{-(-2) \pm \sqrt{(-2)^{2}-4(1)(5)}}{2(1)}\\ &= \frac{2 \pm \sqrt{-16}}{2}\\ &= \frac{2 \pm 4i}{2}\\ &= 1 \pm 2i\end{aligned}\]

Using \(\displaystyle \lambda_a = 1 + 2i\), we have the eigenvector which can be computed by

\(\begin{bmatrix} 3-( 1 + 2i) & -2 \\ 4 & -1-( 1 + 2i) \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 1-i & -1 \\ 2 & -1-i \end{bmatrix}\)

Multiplying the first row with 1+i we obtain \(\begin{bmatrix} 2 & -1-i \\ 2 & -1-i \end{bmatrix} =\begin{bmatrix} 2 & -(1+i) \\ 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}\)

The eigenvector \(\displaystyle v_a\) is such that \(\displaystyle 2v_{a,1} -(1+i)v_{a,2} = 0\). Choosing \(v_{a,1} = 1\) we have \(v_{a,2} = \frac2{i+1} = \frac{2(i-1)}{(i+1)(i-1)} = 1-i\), hence the eigenvector we find is

\(v_a = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 1-i \end{bmatrix}\)

Important: Please keep in mind that this is one possible eigenvector and there are others that differ from this by a scalar multiple. Since the eigenvalues \(\displaystyle \lambda_a,\lambda_b\) are complex conjugate, the eigenvector \(\displaystyle v_b\) is the complex conjugate of \(\displaystyle v_a\), which is

\(v_b = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 1+i \end{bmatrix}\)

Now we calculate by using Eulers formula, \(\displaystyle e^{x+iy} = e^x(\cos(y) + i\sin(y))\),

\[\begin{aligned} v_a e^{\lambda_a t} &= \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1-i\end{bmatrix} e^{(1+2i)t} \\ &= \begin{bmatrix}1\\1-i \end{bmatrix} e^t(\cos(2t) + i\sin(2t))\\ &= \begin{bmatrix} e^t\cos(2t) + i e^t\sin(2t) \\ e^t(\cos(2t)+\sin(2t)) + ie^t(\sin(2t) - \cos(2t)) \end{bmatrix}\\ &= e^t\begin{bmatrix} \cos(2t) \\ \cos(2t)+\sin(2t) \end{bmatrix} + i e^t\begin{bmatrix} \sin(2t) \\ \sin(2t) - \cos(2t) \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

Hence, the real solution of \(\displaystyle y\) is given by

\(y(t) = C_1 e^t\begin{bmatrix} \cos(2t) \\ \cos(2t)+\sin(2t) \end{bmatrix} + C_2 e^t\begin{bmatrix} \sin(2t) \\ \sin(2t) - \cos(2t) \end{bmatrix}\)

for constants \(\displaystyle C_1, C_2\).

’’Note: For the general (complex) solution you would not drop the part \(\displaystyle v_be^{\lambda_b t}\) and the solution would be

\(\displaystyle y(t) = B_1 v_ae^{\lambda_at} + B_2v_be^{\lambda_bt}\)

for constants \(\displaystyle B_1, B_2\). But for the real solution, it is enough to only consider \(\displaystyle v_a e^{\lambda_at}\).”
sols_latex:
To begin, we compute the eigenvalues of the matrix from
{part
(a)} (call this matrix \emph{M}). To start, compute the characteristic
polynomial.

\begin{align*}
\det(M-\lambda I) &= \det\left(
\begin{bmatrix}
3 & -2 \\
4 & -1
\end{bmatrix}
- \lambda \begin{bmatrix}
1 & 0 \\
0 & 1
\end{bmatrix}\right) \\
&= \det\left(
\begin{bmatrix}
3-\lambda & -2 \\
4 & -1-\lambda
\end{bmatrix}\right) \\
&= (3-\lambda)(-1-\lambda)-(-2)(4) \\
&= -3 -2\lambda +\lambda^{2} + 8\\
&= \lambda^{2} -2\lambda + 5 
\end{align*}

This polynomial has two complex roots given by

\begin{align*}
\lambda &= \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^{2}-4ac}}{2a}\\
&= \frac{-(-2) \pm \sqrt{(-2)^{2}-4(1)(5)}}{2(1)}\\
&= \frac{2 \pm \sqrt{-16}}{2}\\
&= \frac{2 \pm 4i}{2}\\
&= 1 \pm 2i
\end{align*}

Using $\displaystyle \lambda_a = 1 + 2i$, we have the eigenvector which
can be computed by

$\begin{bmatrix}
3-( 1 + 2i) & -2 \\
4 & -1-( 1 + 2i)
\end{bmatrix}
=
\begin{bmatrix}
1-i & -1 \\
2 & -1-i
\end{bmatrix}$

Multiplying the first row with \emph{1+i} we obtain $\begin{bmatrix}
2 & -1-i \\
2 & -1-i
\end{bmatrix}
=\begin{bmatrix}
2 & -(1+i) \\
0 & 0
\end{bmatrix}$

The eigenvector $\displaystyle v_a$ is such that
$\displaystyle 2v_{a,1} -(1+i)v_{a,2} = 0$. Choosing $v_{a,1} = 1$ we
have $v_{a,2} = \frac2{i+1} = \frac{2(i-1)}{(i+1)(i-1)} = 1-i$, hence
the eigenvector we find is

$v_a = \begin{bmatrix}
1 \\
1-i
\end{bmatrix}$

\textbf{Important:} Please keep in mind that this is one possible
eigenvector and there are others that differ from this by a scalar
multiple. Since the eigenvalues $\displaystyle \lambda_a,\lambda_b$ are
complex conjugate, the eigenvector $\displaystyle v_b$ is the complex
conjugate of $\displaystyle v_a$, which is

$v_b = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 1+i \end{bmatrix}$

Now we calculate by using Eulers formula,
$\displaystyle e^{x+iy} = e^x(\cos(y) + i\sin(y))$,

\begin{align*}
v_a e^{\lambda_a t} &= \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1-i\end{bmatrix} e^{(1+2i)t} \\
&= \begin{bmatrix}1\\1-i \end{bmatrix} e^t(\cos(2t) + i\sin(2t))\\
&= \begin{bmatrix} e^t\cos(2t) + i e^t\sin(2t) \\ e^t(\cos(2t)+\sin(2t)) + ie^t(\sin(2t) - \cos(2t)) \end{bmatrix}\\
&=  e^t\begin{bmatrix} \cos(2t) \\ \cos(2t)+\sin(2t) \end{bmatrix} + i e^t\begin{bmatrix}  \sin(2t) \\  \sin(2t) - \cos(2t) \end{bmatrix}
\end{align*}

Hence, the \textbf{real} solution of $\displaystyle y$ is given by

$y(t) = C_1 e^t\begin{bmatrix} \cos(2t) \\ \cos(2t)+\sin(2t) \end{bmatrix} + C_2 e^t\begin{bmatrix}  \sin(2t) \\  \sin(2t) - \cos(2t) \end{bmatrix}$

for constants $\displaystyle C_1, C_2$.

'\textbf{'Note:} For the general (complex) solution you would
\textbf{not} drop the part $\displaystyle v_be^{\lambda_b t}$ and the
solution would be

$\displaystyle y(t) = B_1 v_ae^{\lambda_at} + B_2v_be^{\lambda_bt}$

for constants $\displaystyle B_1, B_2$. But for the real solution, it is
enough to only consider $\displaystyle v_a e^{\lambda_at}$.''

To begin, we compute the eigenvalues of the matrix from [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH152/April_2013/Question_B_06_(a)|part (a)]] (call this matrix ''M''). To start, compute the characteristic polynomial.

<math>
\begin{align}
\det(M-\lambda I) &= \det\left(
\begin{bmatrix}
3 & -2 \\
4 & -1
\end{bmatrix}
- \lambda \begin{bmatrix}
1 & 0 \\
0 & 1
\end{bmatrix}\right) \\
&= \det\left(
\begin{bmatrix}
3-\lambda & -2 \\
4 & -1-\lambda
\end{bmatrix}\right) \\
&= (3-\lambda)(-1-\lambda)-(-2)(4) \\
&= -3 -2\lambda +\lambda^{2} + 8\\
&= \lambda^{2} -2\lambda + 5 
\end{align}
</math>

This polynomial has two complex roots given by

<math>
\begin{align}
\lambda &= \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^{2}-4ac}}{2a}\\
&= \frac{-(-2) \pm \sqrt{(-2)^{2}-4(1)(5)}}{2(1)}\\
&= \frac{2 \pm \sqrt{-16}}{2}\\
&= \frac{2 \pm 4i}{2}\\
&= 1 \pm 2i
\end{align}
</math>

Using <math> \displaystyle \lambda_a = 1 + 2i </math>, we have the eigenvector which can be computed by 

<math>
\begin{bmatrix}
3-( 1 + 2i) & -2 \\
4 & -1-( 1 + 2i)
\end{bmatrix}
=
\begin{bmatrix}
1-i & -1 \\
2 & -1-i
\end{bmatrix}
</math>

Multiplying the first row with ''1+i'' we obtain
<math>
\begin{bmatrix}
2 & -1-i \\
2 & -1-i
\end{bmatrix}
=\begin{bmatrix}
2 & -(1+i) \\
0 & 0
\end{bmatrix}
</math>

The eigenvector <math>\displaystyle v_a</math> is such that <math>\displaystyle 2v_{a,1} -(1+i)v_{a,2} = 0</math>. Choosing <math>v_{a,1} = 1</math> we have <math> v_{a,2} = \frac2{i+1} = \frac{2(i-1)}{(i+1)(i-1)} = 1-i </math>, hence the eigenvector we find is

<math>
v_a = \begin{bmatrix}
1 \\
1-i
\end{bmatrix}
</math>

'''Important:''' Please keep in mind that this is one possible eigenvector and there are others that differ from this by a scalar multiple. Since the eigenvalues <math>\displaystyle \lambda_a,\lambda_b</math> are complex conjugate, the eigenvector <math> \displaystyle v_b</math> is the complex conjugate of <math>\displaystyle v_a</math>, which is 

<math> v_b = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 1+i \end{bmatrix} </math> 

Now we calculate by using Eulers formula, <math>\displaystyle e^{x+iy} = e^x(\cos(y) + i\sin(y))</math>,

<math>\begin{align}
 v_a e^{\lambda_a t} &= \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1-i\end{bmatrix} e^{(1+2i)t} \\
&= \begin{bmatrix}1\\1-i \end{bmatrix} e^t(\cos(2t) + i\sin(2t))\\
&= \begin{bmatrix} e^t\cos(2t) + i e^t\sin(2t) \\ e^t(\cos(2t)+\sin(2t)) + ie^t(\sin(2t) - \cos(2t)) \end{bmatrix}\\
&=  e^t\begin{bmatrix} \cos(2t) \\ \cos(2t)+\sin(2t) \end{bmatrix} + i e^t\begin{bmatrix}  \sin(2t) \\  \sin(2t) - \cos(2t) \end{bmatrix}
\end{align}</math> 

Hence, the '''real''' solution of <math>\displaystyle y</math> is given by

<math>
y(t) = C_1 e^t\begin{bmatrix} \cos(2t) \\ \cos(2t)+\sin(2t) \end{bmatrix} + C_2 e^t\begin{bmatrix}  \sin(2t) \\  \sin(2t) - \cos(2t) \end{bmatrix}
</math>


for constants <math>\displaystyle C_1, C_2</math>.



'''''Note:''' For the general (complex) solution you would '''not''' drop the part <math>\displaystyle v_be^{\lambda_b t}</math> and the solution would be

<math> \displaystyle y(t) = B_1 v_ae^{\lambda_at} + B_2v_be^{\lambda_bt}</math>

for constants <math> \displaystyle B_1, B_2 </math>.
But for the real solution, it is enough to only consider <math> \displaystyle v_a e^{\lambda_at}</math>.''
statement_html:
Consider the system of linear differential equations given by

\[\begin{aligned} y'_{1}(t) &= 3y_{1}(t) - 2y_{2}(t)\\ y'_{2}(t) &= 4y_{1}(t) - y_{2}(t)\end{aligned}\]

Find the general solution of this system of differential equations in real form.
statement_latex:
Consider the system of linear differential equations given by

\begin{align*}
y'_{1}(t) &= 3y_{1}(t) - 2y_{2}(t)\\
y'_{2}(t) &= 4y_{1}(t) - y_{2}(t)
\end{align*}

Find the general solution of this system of differential equations
\emph{in real form}.
statement_raw:
Consider the system of linear differential equations given by 

<math>
\begin{align}
y'_{1}(t) &= 3y_{1}(t) - 2y_{2}(t)\\
y'_{2}(t) &= 4y_{1}(t) - y_{2}(t)
\end{align}
</math>

Find the general solution of this system of differential equations ''in real form''.
